registryObject.group: Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

collection.description: Catalogue of all AIHW publications

All AIHW publications are available as free downloads from AIHW website. Some AIHW publications are also available in hardcopy for purchase. The materials on the website are published under a Creative Commons (CC) BY 3.0 licence. Under the terms of this licence, you are required to attribute the AIHW in a form specified by this policy. However, you may not attribute the AIHW in a way that would create an impression that the AIHW endorses your organisation or your work.

registryObject.group: Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

name.namePart: ALCOHOL AND OTHER DRUG TREATMENT SERVICES (NATIONAL MINIMUM DATA SET)

collection.subject: ALCOHOL
AODTS
DRUG
TOBACCO
collection.description: Publications<br>Summary tables published in electronic form.<br>Online interactive Data Cubes.<br>Client specified tables on request which may be subject to data provider approval (charges apply)<br>Restricted unit record access subject to Ethics Committee approval and/or the agreement of all relevant data custodians in all states and territories (charges may apply).

The Alcohol and Other Drug Treatment Services National Minimum Data Set (AODTS NMDS) emanated from the national forum 'treatment and research - where to from here?' held in 1995 by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. In December 1999 the Commonwealth and state and territory governments through the then National Health Information Management Group endorsed a version of the AODTS NMDS for collection to commence on 1 July 2000. The first data were collected for 2000-01; this was considered a pilot year. The data from 2001-02 onwards contain information about alcohol and other drug treatment services; the clients who use these services; the types of drug problems for which treatment is sought and the types of treatment provided.
AODTS Working Group approval required for unreleased state/territory data. AIHW Ethics Committee approval required for access to unit record level data.
Collection Methodology: Official Data

collection.description: Publications<br>Summary tables published in electronic form.<br>Client specified tables on request which may be subject to data provider approval (charges apply)<br>Restricted unit record access subject to Ethics Committee approval and/or the agreement of all relevant data custodians in all states and territories (charges may apply).

A series of surveys auspiced by the National Drug Strategy (and its predecessors and successors). The 1998, 2001, 2004, 2007 and 2010 surveys were conducted by the AIHW. It is a national household survey of non-institutionalised persons aged 14 years and over (12 years and over from 2004).

A confidentialised unit record file for public access is available at the Australian Social Science Data Archives at the ANU: <a href="http://ssda.anu.edu.au" target = "new"> http://ssda.anu.edu.au </a>. (available September 2011 for the not yet available for the 2010 NDSHS) Public access to the master unit record data requires application to the AIHW Ethics Committee.
Sample is designed to be representative at national and state/territory level.
Collection Methodology: Survey

CSDA
DISABILITY
SERVICES

WELFARE
collection.description: Unit records may not be available and there may be restrictions or limitations governing the availability or use of other data in this holding. For more information about availability please call the phone number below

The CSTDA national minimum data set was developed in 1993 and 1994 jointly by all states and territories, the AIHW.The first data collection was undertaken in 1995. The data contains information about services directly provided or funded by government, under the umbrella of the CSTDA. The collection has been redeveloped and, after having been a 'snaphsot' collection, produces full year data from 2002-03.
See annual reports and data guides on links provided.
Collection Methodology: Official Data

relatedInfo.title: Functioning and disability portal, CSDA collection details

registryObject.group: Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

collection.subject: FOD
INDEX
NATIONAL
NDI
collection.description: Unit records may not be available and there may be restrictions or limitations governing the availability or use of other data in this holding. For more information about availability please call the phone number below

The National Death Index (NDI) is a data base developed and maintained by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, in Canberra. The data base is a listing of all deaths that have occurred in Australia since 1980. It is an invaluable tool for epidemiologists and clinicians in following up research cohorts using record linkage.

Linkages of research data files with the NDI are usually done using the following data items: first name, second name, surname, sex, date of birth. Last contact date, if available in the research file, is used to assist in resolving uncertain cases, as may be additional information such as country of birth and state and SLA of usual residence.
All proposals for linkage with the NDI must be approved by the AIHW Ethics Committee.
Collection Methodology: Official Data
